So I want to acknowledge my
co-authors, Samia, Aarushi, who are leading this work.

The rise of robot
waiter, expanding the job characteristics model
in age of automation. But first I want to
give you a background.

My PhD is in information
systems from a business school, so I'm from a business school.

I left the business school. I went to school
information where I thought I would be a business
school professor in school

of information, and
I would do stuff for people at Ross
business school, and that would be my thing.

Turns out I didn't. I spent a lot of time
integrating myself. So in the beginning,
when I was a PhD student,

I was heavily involved in
the Academy of Management. Informs-- you ever
heard of informs before?

Association of
information systems. That was my PhD
community as I came up.

I got a job in business
school, didn't quite like it. I moved to SI,
and then I started

getting involved
in CHI, CSCW where I was applying my same concepts
but to a different community,

much more design focused,
and I was pretty happy there, and then I decided to
do autonomous vehicles

and got involved in robots. I was tapped to join the
university's first autonomous

systems committee,
and there I met other people
involved in robotics

and they had a
robotics institute. And so I started doing AI stuff. And I moved now--

now I do a lot of stuff
in the IEEE community. So I span all three of
those communities, which

can be kind of exhausting.
spend a lot of time going back and
forth, but it does mean that when you
get my presentation,

you're not quite sure
what you're going to get. It could be a business
school presentation, it could be engineering,
human factors, it could be a computer science.

So I'll give you a warning in
that, or something different. So I have two appointments.

I am a post positive. If you don't know what that is,
that's probably a good thing. So don't worry about it.

I have an appointment
in two places-- school Information, Robotics. I play two separate roles.

So in the School
of Information, I'm the guy that does experiments,
randomized studies, interventions, heavy statistics.

I'm the quote unquote,
"horror science person." And then I go to robotics, I'm
the person who studies people,

so I'm like the
soft science person. So depending upon where I
go, I wear two different hats in those places, so
it's pretty interesting.

So we'll go here
to service robots. I like to define things. At Michigan, we separate AI
from robotics in the sense

that a robot has to
have a physical body. So tend to say a
robot is some type

of physical enactment
of AI, and so that's a loose definition of it.

And in this case,
for service robots is thinking about
robots that help humans perform some of service tasks.

The standard business school
motivation, it's a hot topic, but it's growing market. I get a lot of conversations
about people, about robots.

They think they're
going to be around, what role are going to play? Well, they are taking
off faster than ever.

The market is increasing. I say maybe five years
ago, you wouldn't even estimate that things
would be this fast.

That being the case,
there are some benefits. You see a lot about
the benefits of robots,

in particular service robots,
communication, data analysis, productivity, all your standard.

I want to sell you
a service robot, and here's why they're good. Which you don't hear less
about are the challenges.

A big challenge is
fear of job loss. People don't like
working with something they think are going
to replace their job. Frustration, a loss of autonomy,
depersonalization, surveillance.

Surveillance is the other
side of the data analysis

coin and competition. People sometimes
feel like they're competing with the robot.

So it takes us back
to the big picture. I get asked to do interviews
all the time, and people say, our robots are going
to take all the jobs,

blah, blah, blah, blah, blah. And the answer to
that question is no. It turns out that humans
are pretty useful.

So going forward,
you're going to have a human-robot hybrid workforce.

So that goes the
idea of let's move away from the fear of robots
and all their problems to one

where we can build some synergy
between humans and robots collaboration. And so for me, the big
picture of this research

question in this topic
that I'm exploring, how can we provide quality
work for employees,

collaborating with robots,
ensuring that their work remains engaging, meaningful,
and satisfying

while promoting human robot
synergy in the workplace? Now you might say,
why restaurants?

Turns out restaurants are
incredibly interesting places. One, labor is a huge component
of the cost of restaurants.

Two, the restaurant
industry is one of the largest private
employers in the country.

Huge amount of
people, huge turnover. That's part of the reason
why they want to use robots.

But huge turnover also means
you got issues of training, bringing people in there,
but it's a huge issue.

Technology-- I mean,
restaurants surprisingly have an incredibly high
rate of technology adoption.

At first hand, you would
say that's surprising. But if you think
about it, restaurants are quick to adopt the
latest technology faster

than any other workplace
we have or just as fast, and turns out they have
a very diverse workforce.

Most of the minority managers,
they get their first break at managing, private
sector is at a restaurant,

and restaurants tend to be the
first job for a lot of people.

So they actually basically
provide a very unique ecosystem to understanding how humans
and robots work together.

If you have any
questions, feel free. I mean, if it's going to--
if you have any questions, let me know.

If I'm going to answer it
later, I'll also tell you. Here's some examples
of robots that you would find in restaurants.

There's Flippy. Has anyone heard
of Flippy before? Yeah, White Castle
uses Flippy a lot.

That's a big thing. There is Hyper-Robotics
which make pizza. The Bellabots or some version
of it are quite popular.

People use that a
lot in restaurants. It'd be surprising there's a
robot, I think downtown here.

I forgot what shop it is,
but you would be surprised. Almost every town has at
least one service robot

in the restaurant. The penetration is huge. And there's, of
course, the Barobot.

A lot of bars are-- a lot
of restaurants are making-- a lot of robots
are making drinks. That tend to be a pretty
popular application of it.

So going back here, I'm
asking myself, OK, robots are going to be here. They're not going anywhere.

How can we create an
environment where people can work with them together? And it turns out this
question that I'm

asking about humans
working with automation, and how can we make the
work more meaningful, it turns out it's
not a new question.

It's a surprisingly
old question. So old question that
started off when we went from the pre-industrial
age, so here in this age,

if you were a dress
maker, you probably learn how to make a dress
from your mom or your aunt.

You probably made
the entire dress. If you made dresses,
you were a dress maker. That was the pre-industrial age.

And we moved to
the industrial age where basically corporations. if you made dresses, you
would not a dress maker.

You made one small
part of that dress. So we went from a job
that was like an identity,

you had autonomy,
it was who you are, to basically being something
you did to make a living,

not identifying with it, being
routine, boring and tedious. And so when that
happens, there were

a lot of people who
ask the question, how can we make this work much
more meaningful and enduring?

And out of that
conversation came something called the job
characteristics model.

Has anyone ever
heard of that before? Anybody in-- pretty
popular in business. So developed in the 1970s
by Hackman and Oldham.

Basically, the
goal was to ensure that employees remained engaged
and motivated and satisfied with work.

The theoretical
foundation, because it's important to remember that,
it's both a theory as well

as something people use
in practical applications to identify the key
factors that lead to work that was motivating,
satisfying, and engaging.

And it provides this
structured approach to look at the job
and the job design.

It goes like this-- so
they identified five job characteristics that promote
psychological states that lead

to what they consider
the four outcomes-- motivation, performance,
satisfaction, and turnover.

I'll walk you through
each of these. So the five job characteristics,
skill variety, goes like this.

To what degree the job
requires a lot of skill, a variety of skill.

You're going to enjoy it more. You're going to it. It's a positive. Task identity-- to what degree
you can do a whole task instead

of a part task. So let me give an example. To what degree you're going to
make an entire chair as opposed

to one leg? The entire chair would
be high task identity. You tend to enjoy that more.

To what degree you
think your job is important to the organization? Task significance. It's positive.

To what degree
you have autonomy? Autonomy is to what degree
you have the ability to choose how you do your job.

Some form of speech and
feedback to what degree you were told how you were
doing a job, giving information.

All those things were the
five most important job characteristics, and they
more or less impacted

psychological states. First one was job
meaningfulness. To what degree you believe your
job, of course, was meaningful.

That's responsibility. To what degree you felt like
you had a lot of responsibility in your job, and that's
knowledge of results.

To what degree you knew how
well you were doing in your job. And those things
led to an employee

being more motivated,
more energy-- more engaged to perform the
job, perform the job better.

They were more satisfied
with their job, and they were less
likely to quit their job. That was the job
characteristics model.

To become a bit more
academic in detail. There were three
overarching hypotheses. So one in particular, skill
variety, task identity,

task significant, all
promoted job meaningfulness. And if you promote
job meaningfulness,

that led to employees being
motivated, performance satisfaction, and reduce
chances where they

were going to quit their job. The next one here, job
autonomy led to increases

in responsibility that had
the same positive impact, and then the same
thing with-- feedback

increases knowledge
of results that lead to the positive outcomes.

These were the things. So it's important to know
that job characteristics is very popular model used
to guide job design.

So if you were going to
design a new job tomorrow, you could use this to determine
the outcome of the employees.

If people were unhappy
with their job, you can use this to determine
why and how to improve that.

And you also have trade offs. You can say to
what degree are we going to increase
productivity, but we don't want to make people too miserable?

You can use this. I'm also hoping over and
above this that not only that we're going to apply this
with people working with robots,

but over and above
that, that this also could be used to understand
how to facilitate, how to design better work
technology to extend that

to that realm. This also aligns, if
you're in academia, there's been a lot of calls
in academia asking scholars

to try to view these intelligent
technologies in different ways and traditional automation,
and to develop, if not extend

theories that we currently
have to these new contexts. That's been across the board
in organizational behavior,

research, or science
research, but particularly in the study of
providing services.

People were asking scholars to
come up with or extend theories to find out how to keep people
engaged when they're working out

with AI and robotics. So that would narrow down
the research question

here, which is what insights can
the job characteristics model provide into enhancing
job quality for employees,

collaborating robots,
ensuring that work remains engaging, meaningful
and satisfying, and promoting workplace?

Now we're going to do
this in two studies. The first study is
an exploratory study.

To be fair, it was
conducted during COVID. So the end of COVID. It's much more
exploratory where we

try to survey employees who
are restaurant employees, not working with robots. To see what degree they think
the job is going to change

any problems they see. We completed by
almost two years ago. Then we have a second study
that we're just completing.

The second study much
more confirmatory. They're both mixed
methods approaches. These are about 424
restaurant employees who

are working with robots now. And we just completed the
second wave of that, so some of that data.

So study 1, convergent
mixed method study. When I say mixed method-- go ahead.

Was there overlap
between participants. No, that's a good question. There's no overlap. Both of these were
random samples.

They're not the
same organization. So it's a great question. So basically it's a mixed method
study with quant and qualitative

analysis. Am I familiar with that? We'll talk about that
in a little bit more. A random sampling,
established scales.
So scales. So it kind of went like this. So we surveyed employees.

We basically had a survey
where basically they were asked questions-- is the example-- example, one question
for task identity, work--

do you think work on robot will
either increase or decrease your opportunity to complete
the work that you start?

If they put down, greatly
decrease or greatly increase

or increase,
OpenText box appeared

if they indicated they thought

they would be an extreme
change to their job, they would basically-- they get a chance to explain
exactly why they thought

that was going to happen. What is it about the job they
thought was going to change. Give me an example. Question.

So this was how we got the
quant and the qualitative data. The 220 restaurant
employees, age,

what you expect, so
gender breakdown, they worked over
eight hours a day, so this is a good sample
of restaurant employees.

it all met the requirements
for me with that. So I'll walk through
the quant analysis. So for hypothesis 1, we

except for skill variety
and task identity. There was no evidence

or had a relationship
with job meaningfulness, but in this case,
job meaningfulness

or anticipated changes. It led to anticipated
changes in the outcomes.

Hypothesis 2, similar

did show increases

in job responsibility
that were associated. That led to more-- that
had impact on motivation, but did not have an impact
on performance satisfaction

or turnover intention. Hypothesis 3,
basically feedback led

to knowledge of
results and, of course, that was significant changes
except for turnover intention.

So we found some evidence that
said, OK, this model could work to predict the
behavior, at least

from the quantum standpoint. Then we engage in the
actual qualitative analysis where we actually
had the observation

of the text coding where they
actually explained the examples. So we engage in something we
call bridging and brackets.

So when it comes
to as I call it, a mixed method study,
when you bridge,

you're trying to find
examples of evidence that supports what you find
with the quantitative data.

When you go and you
go and you bracket, you try to find examples to
explain the opposite of that,

to say, OK, why
didn't we find this? So we have a pretty-- we went to a lot of
analysis dramatically.

So for example, for the
first one, we call--

what they [? see, ?] so

was there any emergent

What would be different? What would be the
things they might have. And there were two emergent
themes that popped up.

So one of them was we
labeled perceived usefulness with the employee.

To what degree the
robot is perceived to be useful with the employee,
humans will retain their job,

so humans will retain their
jobs and make them better. So typically there
are people who

thought the robot would help
them do better in their job and they were pretty
excited about it. They thought, OK, this is great.

Robots are going to
help me be better. And so comments like,
working in a tag team way,

as I'm doing one thing,
the robot can do another. I'm getting drinks,
robots taking orders. So there was a lot of comments
like, hey, this is really

going to help me out, man. This is really cool. Make me a better employee. On the other hand,
there were comments

we call perceived usefulness
without the employee. To what degree the robot
is going to do something

without the employee? Does not need the employee help. And so that was perceived
usefulness without the employee.

Comments like, the robots
will be taking over jobs, so people would be
performing less tasks.

It would make me depressed
like I was being outsourced or something. These are [? second ?]
comments we call them.

two new constructs we thought might be useful
in understanding how the job

characteristics model
